update.description:
See `subt-communication/README.md` for more details regarding this refactor of the existing virtual communication system for SUBT. It involves four new packages that replace and extend functionality that was previously in the `subt_gazebo` package. The `subt_gazebo` package continues to hold the Gazebo plugin that instantiates communication simulation:

* `subt_rf_interface`: Provides function signature \(and simple implementation\) for computing pathloss from transmitter/receiver locations.
* `subt_communication_model`: Provides function signature and implementation for evaluating packet communication success based on evaluation of a path loss function, modulation-based models of bit-error rate, and bitrate limitations of the configured radio.
* `subt_communication_broker`: Centralized node that handles communication requests via distributed client API. Is instantiated with function handles for \(1\) a pathloss function, \(2\) an `attempt_send` function, i.e., the communication model, and \(3\) an `update_pose` function that provides a mechanism to query the simulator for the pose of an agent by name.
* `subt_gazebo_los_model`: Pathloss function instantiation based on approximate visibility via a pre-computed lookup table. The so-called _visibility cost_ is used to affect the fading exponent for the generic range-based log-normal fading model. This means communication while in line-of-sight \(LOS\) will behave according to standard fading models and as LOS is lost, attenuation will happen much more rapidly.

**Note**: After this PR is merged, some validation/model-fitting should be performed along with testing in simulation to choose good parameters \(fading exponent, noise floor, link capacity, mapping visibility cost to fading exponent inflation\) that match somewhat realistic devices.

**Some other changes along the way include**:

* Add service to subt\_example for testing comms

    _Service will create pair of topics for externally analyzing communication peformance \(bitrate acheieved, latency, etc\)_


* Add subt\_comms\_test

    _Package to store communication system testing nodes and scripts._


* Fix subt\_example\_node comms LED blinking

    _LED blinking was limiting communication rate._


* Improved visibility visualization

    * _Improve speed of rendering using POINTS marker type_
    * _color-code points based on computed cost_
update.title: Comms refactor

content.raw: Thanks!
content.html: Thanks!

content.raw: Yes, just did a test with this with a burst size of 102400 \(100, 1024 byte packets\) to better align with the queue size used by the subt\_example\_node and performance with simple mode is as expected.
content.html: Yes, just did a test with this with a burst size of 102400 (100, 1024 byte packets) to better align with the queue size used by the subt_example_node and performance with simple mode is as expected.

content.html: I suspect this is due to queue size on either the ROS subscriber or publisher for the subt_example_node (only 100 right now)…

content.raw: Out of curiosity, is there any reason for using this ROS data structure here? Unless you plan to send it over the network it's probably more convenient to use something like `ignition::math::Pose3d`, which gives you all the manipulations for free. I believe you need to compute at least the distance between 3D points.
content.html: Out of curiosity, is there any reason for using this ROS data structure here? Unless you plan to send it over the network it's probably more convenient to use something like ignition::math::Pose3d, which gives you all the manipulations for free. I believe you need to compute at least the distance between 3D points.

content.raw: Thanks. Can you mention this detail in the documentation of the `CommsBrokerBlugin`? I just want to make sure that everybody understands that if you're using the `log_normal_range` comms model type you'll need extra files. On the other hand, `visibility_range` should work without any external file.
content.html: Thanks. Can you mention this detail in the documentation of the CommsBrokerBlugin? I just want to make sure that everybody understands that if you're using the log_normal_range comms model type you'll need extra files. On the other hand, visibility_range should work without any external file.

content.raw: Correct.
content.html: Correct.

content.raw: And the `log_normal_range` doesn't use the visibility information contained in the graph?
content.html: And the log_normal_range doesn't use the visibility information contained in the graph?

content.raw: The “visibility\_range” model \(which uses visibility heuristic to adjust the parameters of the log-normal range model\) actually relies on both of these sets of configurations. I kept them separate since you can use a range model without the visibility piece.
content.html: The “visibility_range” model (which uses visibility heuristic to adjust the parameters of the log-normal range model) actually relies on both of these sets of configurations. I kept them separate since you can use a range model without the visibility piece.

content.raw: I just want to make sure that I understand this correctly...Are `range_model` and `visibility_model` two options of `rf_configuration` and the user needs to choose only one of them or both models are required?
content.html: I just want to make sure that I understand this correctly...Are range_model and visibility_model two options of rf_configuration and the user needs to choose only one of them or both models are required?

content.raw: Jon, can you document here the SDF parameters of the comms\_model \(or at least the most relevants\)? It’s also important to know if something is required or optional. Using an example at the end would be great. [Here](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/bd1cdea8fa3d71d6afcdaa83c9b01891d5f72e71/plugins/ArduCopterPlugin.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default)’s a plugin that you can use as a template.
content.html: Jon, can you document here the SDF parameters of the comms_model (or at least the most relevants)? It’s also important to know if something is required or optional. Using an example at the end would be great. Here’s a plugin that you can use as a template.

content.html: Thanks! I can communicate between robots using the joystick in tunnel_practice_1 and tunnel_qual but not in tunnel_practice_2. I get a No pathloss function defined for X1 error message.

content.raw: It helps visually but I don’t pretend to open that rabbit hole of style discussions. It’s a convention that we follow in the code \(and in Gazebo and other libraries\) and as any other convention, there are people that like it and others that don’t. But at least the code is consistent, which is the best part.
content.html: It helps visually but I don’t pretend to open that rabbit hole of style discussions. It’s a convention that we follow in the code (and in Gazebo and other libraries) and as any other convention, there are people that like it and others that don’t. But at least the code is consistent, which is the best part.

content.raw: Agree re: disruption. Perhaps some sort of migration documentation could be added? I have updated the subt\_example node and it was quite straightforward.
content.html: Agree re: disruption. Perhaps some sort of migration documentation could be added? I have updated the subt_example node and it was quite straightforward.

content.raw:
Shuffling would create out-of-order packet delivery which isn’t entirely realistic in a point-to-point wireless setting \(especially when we consider unreliable transport, re-sends could potentially introduce some out-of-order delivery\).

I think shuffling was originally used to keep a single node from starving out other nodes due to rate-limiting on the shared channel. With small packet sizes, I think we are unlikely to see this happen \(certainly not in my testing\). Messages coming in from multiple clients at similar rates will mix somewhat uniformly \(so there shouldn’t be a bias in terms of service\).
content.html:
Shuffling would create out-of-order packet delivery which isn’t entirely realistic in a point-to-point wireless setting (especially when we consider unreliable transport, re-sends could potentially introduce some out-of-order delivery).

I think shuffling was originally used to keep a single node from starving out other nodes due to rate-limiting on the shared channel. With small packet sizes, I think we are unlikely to see this happen (certainly not in my testing). Messages coming in from multiple clients at similar rates will mix somewhat uniformly (so there shouldn’t be a bias in terms of service).

content.html: Could you also update worlds/tunnel_practice_2 and worlds/tunnel_qual?

content.html: No, I don’t use the rndEngine any more, could be removed. I left commented in case we wanted to easily restore.
